title: What is Git?
intro: Welcome to the Git basics lesson.
explanation: Git helps developers track and collaborate on code changes.

stages.label: Full Quiz

questions.hint: It's used to track changes in code.
questions.explanation: Git is a version control system that helps you manage and track changes to code over time.

questions.text: Why is Git useful for developers?
questions.hint: Developers need to manage versions of their code.
questions.explanation: Git tracks versions of your files, so you can go back to earlier code and collaborate safely.

questions.text: Git was created by the same person who created Linux.
questions.explanation: Linus Torvalds, the creator of Linux, also created Git in 2005.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Git?
options: It requires an internet connection to work
questions.answer: It requires an internet connection to work
questions.explanation: Git works locally — you don’t need to be online to use it.

questions.hint: Think 'version control' — it manages different versions of your project.
questions.explanation: Version control systems manage changes to source code over time.

questions.text: Match the Git concept to its description.

pairs.Branch: A parallel version of the project

questions.hint: Think of commits as save points in a video game.
questions.explanation: Repositories hold your project, commits track history, and branches allow different lines of work.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Git command?
questions.explanation: `git init` creates a new Git repository in your current folder.

questions.text: The command to create a new Git repository is `git ____`.
questions.explanation: `git init` sets up a new Git repo in the current folder.

questions.text: What does a Git commit do?
questions.hint: Think of it like saving your game.
questions.explanation: A commit saves your current work and includes a message describing the change.

questions.text: Git can help teams of developers work on the same project at the same time without overwriting each other’s work.
questions.hint: Branches help teams work in parallel.
questions.explanation: Git lets developers work on separate branches, preventing conflicts until changes are merged.

stages.review_prompt: Think of Git like a time machine for your code. Every change is a checkpoint.
